headline: Legal showdown looms as Democrats prepare court challenges to Trump's national emergency
subHeadline: President Trump declares a national emergency on the southern border to free up new wall funding; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello everyone. I am Dana Perino along with Jedediah Bila, Juan Williams, Pete Heseth and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is “The Five.” This is a Fox News alert. Police is saying the suspect in an Aurora, Illinois industrial park shooting has been neutralized. According to the city of Aurora, four police officers were wounded in the incident and are in stable condition. We go now to Jonathan Hunt for the latest. Jonathan.

utterances.speaker: JONATHAN HUNT, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Dana, the first 9-11 calls came in at around 1:40 central time, that's 2:40 p.m. eastern. Now, we do not know from officials how this incident played out exactly. We are expecting a news conference with local police and other officials at the bottom of the hour. They will give us the blow-by-blow of what they know.  But what we have heard from eyewitnesses is that a worker at the Henry Pratt Company, which is the building you are looking at right there, checked in for work like it was any normal day this morning. And several hours later suddenly began running through that building in the words of this eyewitness, "shooting everyone."  We know officially now that four police officers were wounded in this. We assume and it is only an assumption at this point that they were among the first officers to respond after those initial 9-11 calls. We are also being told that all four of those are in stable condition. Beyond that, we do not know the extent of their injuries. We also do know, though, that the coroner is now on scene. Obviously a coroner is only called in if there are bodies to be dealt with. So again, our assumption here with the coroner on scene is that at least one person is dead. Whether that is a victim or whether that is indeed the shooter, we do not know. The language that officials have used regarding the shooter has changed.  The first word we got was from the city of Aurora. They said the shooter had been "apprehended." Then a city of Aurora spokesman later changed that talking with (inaudible) news team to the shooter has been "neutralized." And then Aurora police said the shooter is no longer a threat. So, all of these questions -- what is the condition of the shooter? What is the condition of those injured? We hope to get some answers too in the next 30 minutes or so. But the bottom line, there has been a mass shooting in Aurora, Illinois, west of Chicago. The shooter is neutralized, whatever that means according to officials.  There is no longer a threat. Schools in the area went on immediate lockdown. They have now been told they can lift that lockdown and parents can go and pick up their children, so a sense of relief now there. The area was flooded with first responders, SWAT officers. We saw them at one point rushing into the building and that appeared to coincide with those first reports we got that the shooter had been apprehended.   Now we have seen a lot of those first responders standing around far more relaxed fashion, weapons down. Clearly the threat is over as Aurora police have told us, but we wait now, Dana, to find out the details from officials of exactly what prompted this shooting and exactly what is the condition of those four police officers who were hurt, and any other people who were shot in this attack, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you Jonathan. We appreciate it. We are monitoring any developments out of Aurora, Illinois as Jonathan said and we will update you as we get them. President Trump fighting back against critics during a fiery Rose Garden news conference where he officially declared a national emergency on the southern border.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: We are going to be signing today and registering a national emergency and it's a great thing to do because we have an invasion of drugs, invasion of gangs, invasion of people and it's unacceptable. I could do the wall over a longer period of time. I didn't need to do this, but I would rather do it much faster. And I don't have to do it for the election. I've already done a lot of wall for the election 2020. And the only reason we are up here talking about this is because of the election.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi blasted the decision as a "power grab." They are signaling that Democrats will fight it out in courts. President Trump sarcastically responded to any potential legal challenges.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We will have a national emergency and we will then be sued and they will sue us in the Ninth Circuit even though it shouldn't be there. And we will possibly get a bad ruling and then we'll get another bad ruling and then we will end up in the Supreme Court and hopefully we'll get a fair shake and we'll win in the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know. He was talking about how this has been a civics lesson, the last -- he's right. It's now just how the bill becomes a law, it's how the bill goes to court.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, he said it in such kind of, a nice sing-songy (ph) way that even a child like in the (inaudible). OK, so the thing that -- we have to remind everybody when you are listening to smug reporters that when the caravans were here, it was a national emergency.  At that time America was being compared to Nazi Germany because we were separating -- remember we were separating families and putting children in cages. It was a horrifying humanitarian crisis. So you finally get that the president to agree that this is an unacceptable situation and we should apply some solutions, and some of the Democrats are mocking it. It's no longer an emergency even though we said that it was like Nazi Germany just months ago. So for the media and for the Democrats, the caravan is a national emergency until it's no longer visual. So, what you are left with are adults trying to solve the underlying issue that led to this crisis, which is, I mean, think about this.  Whether it is terror or mass shootings, you don't just assume everything is fine when the attack is over. You go back and you figure out how do you prevent that. That's all that is going on right now. And to laugh at this and say it's not a humanitarian crisis, you were the same people screaming bloody murder that it was.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That it was. We have sound from one of the exchanges with a reporter. You're going to want to talk about this. Pete, take a listen.

utterances.speaker: JOM ACOSTA, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: What do you say to your critics who say that you are creating a national emergency and you're concocting a national emergency in order to get your wall?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I asked the Angel Moms. What do you think? Do you think I'm creating something? Ask these incredible women who lost their daughters and their sons, OK. Because your question is a very political question because you have an agenda.  No, no, you get one. Just wait. Sit down! Sit down. You get one question.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No, the second question is --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Wait! Sit down. Sit down!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Could you please answer --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Sit down. You get one question.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Pete, you are sitting.

utterances.speaker: PETE HEGSETH, HOST
utterances.sentences: I said the same thing to my kids last night - -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Stand up, Pete.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Sit, sit. I will say, you talked about visuals, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: The Angel Moms were the most powerful part of this press conference. He used them in his opening remarks and then when Jim Acosta tried to come at him and used the stats to talk about the stats. He said, there you -- the left does the emotional visuals so well so often. And we rarely see that from conservatives or Republicans because we talk stats --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, if you do they get made fun off.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Yes, they get made fun when we talk stats, but that visual right there. These are people affected by this. And the comparison is, remember when the left and the media went wall-to-wall on the very unfortunate circumstance for the two kids who were handed over to ICE in custody as their parents brought them on their perilous journey passed away after everything we do for them.  There was wall-to-wall coverage. There is almost no coverage other than this channel on these Angel Moms and these circumstances when illegals go wrong. That's the point the president is making. I think a lot of people watching this feel that vicerally (ph).

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, HOST
utterances.sentences: And did Acosta asked President Obama, Nancy Pelosi and all the Democrats? Did he stop them and say, you know, is this a manufactured humanitarian crisis when they were all out there calling? There were clips of Obama and Pelosi and all these Democrats calling it and acknowledging that this was a humanitarian crisis.   No reporters questioned them when they all said, oh yes, they want to address it. They want to do something about it. He had no choice but to do this national emergency. This was not my first choice.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He did have a choice.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I mean, he could have taken the origin deal which was terrible. He could have taken this new bill that is an atrocity as I said yesterday. But the bottomline is, as I said yesterday also, it's either national emergency or it's not. And he was in a position now where he felt like there is no movement for me here. I am not getting any help from Democrats. They are not interested at this point in calling this what it is which is a national emergency because to do that would give me a victory in 2020 or it gives some credence to what I've been saying.   So unless I actually declare this and figure out a way to move some of this money around, I'm not going to get the money for the wall. They're not interested in the barriers and they put so many obstacles forth in the spending bill that, you know, you can't have this type of wall. You can't have a wall of that type in this place, enabling towns and counties --

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: You can't disrupt the butterflies.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: -- right. You can't do anything essentially.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Let me mention, Juan, that in my ear, they tell me that just FYI, the House Judiciary Committee has announced that they are launching an immediate investigation into this executive action. They have sent letters to the president to that effect. Let's get you thoughts. You haven't spoken yet.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, I think the key thing for me is that the Justice Department tone is a high litigation risk with this strategy. I don't think there is an emergency of any kind. To say there is a humanitarian crisis, well, I guess there was a humanitarian crisis in December. I guess there was a humanitarian crisis two years ago.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So you don't want to fix it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me finish. And so you have a situation where he didn't declare an emergency then. Now today, and I think this was telling, he says, you know what? I don't need to do this, but I would rather do it faster. Boy, if I was a lawyer, I would say, your honor, the president said he doesn't need to do this. There is no invasion. There is nobody attacking America. This is not a military situation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When another child dies you will change your mind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, this is a situation where I think it was Ann Coulter, a real conservative, who said the only national emergency is the president is an idiot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Now you agree with Ann Coulter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And so this is -- but to me --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: She tweeted (ph) (inaudible) everyday how she feels about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- but to me, you look at the idea of the national emergency and what I see is that you guys are saying, well, maybe because you want to support the president. I can appreciate that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I got to tell you something, the "Wall Street Journal" editorial page, "National Review," I could even go on the number of Republicans in the Senate including Mitch McConnell, Senate Majority, who tried to get the president to say don't do this because there is one day going to be President Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and boy, you don't want to give her this authority.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what, what is great now is I want to hear the Dems tell me that fentanyl is no longer a problem, human trafficking is not longer a problem, gang violence is no longer a problem, sexual abuse is no longer a problem. The Dems are walking into a huge trap. It's already happening. You saw it with Beto.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can we play that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, certainly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Watch this.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS HAYES, MSNBC HOST
utterances.sentences: If you could, would you take the wall down now here, like you have a wall?

utterances.speaker: BETO O'ROURKE, D-TX, FORMER CONGRESSMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: HAYES
utterances.sentences: You'll knock it down.

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.sentences: I'd take the wall down

utterances.speaker: HAYES
utterances.sentences: Do you think the city -- do you think there is a referendum here in the city that would pass?

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.sentences: I do, but it has cost us tens of billion dollars to build and to maintain. And it has pushed migrants and asylum seekers and refugees to the most inhospitable, the most hostile stretches of the U.S.-Mexico border ensuring their suffering and death.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, that will come back.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, OK. This is -- we talked about this a couple of weeks ago that if they believe something is immoral, shouldn't you remove the existing immorality?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And that is the existing walls. So, it's a trap that they've walked into and now he says, and you know who else suggest, Kirsten Gillibrand. Is it Jillibrand or Gillibrand?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Gillibrand.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Whatever, anyway, the point is now -- Gillibrand, thank you. So, the fact is each one is now going to be faced with this question wherever they go and they're going to have to -- they have two choices. Remove the immorality or side with Trump.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: It's not a case of --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And Kirsten.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Kirsten.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: It's not a case of how of whether the national emergency is now or two months ago. The president has said it's an emergency for that long. Congress can't figure it out. They can't address it. They haven't been able to deal with the emergency as a result as the executive who is charged with our security. He says I have to take it in my own hands.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What security? It is not a security issue. It is a joke.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Drugs.

utterances.speaker: WILLAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, let's go see this -- no, let me finish up here. And you know, when the president says, oh, this is about drugs. Most drugs come through legal ports of entry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: When the president says it's about illegal immigration, gues what, illegal immigration is down substantially like radically since 2000.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Because of walls.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh my, you know it's not because of the wall.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No problems here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you talk about walls. This is -- there are other ways. There is fencing --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You guys, we have to run. We got --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know to me, it's like you don't want to hear it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, we don't want to hear it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Another new twist in the Jussie Smollett case. We're going to bring the details to you, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Breaking news out of Chicago. Police arresting two suspects in the alleged hate crime attack on the "Empire" actor Jussie Smollett. It's the latest new twist in that mysterious but developing story. Chicago police now say they are holding two men identified in security video from the area where Smollett said he was attacked. Smollett claiming two people hurled racist, homophobic slurs at him and told him "This is MAGA country." The suspects have now been identified by police as Nigerian brothers. Police saying one of them worked on the set of "Empire." On Wednesday, Smollett was asked by ABC if the men on the security video were his attackers.

utterances.speaker: JUSSIE SMOLLETT, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: I don't have any doubt in my mind that that's them. Never did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This follows reports by local news outlets that the attack on Smollett was a hoax. Police later responding to that saying it was not a hoax and that Smollettt "continues to be treated as a victim not a suspect." Jedediah, it is such a strange story. It seems to change, but we had these reports in Chicago suggesting that maybe this was something that was staged with these men. One of them had been an extra on the "Empire" show because Smollett was worried that he was going to be written out of the script of "Empire." What do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Which Fox Entertainment came out and said that's not true. He wasn't going to be written out of that. I don't know. It's interesting. And where did those reports originate from because once those reports came out, the Chicago local police came out immediately and said, there is -- we're not going to substantiate this. He's not being investigated. We are not confirming these reports. I don't know what happened here and I don't think any of us do and it remains to be seen. That's why an investigation needs to happen. The thing that interests me most still is his phone records though because now he has turned over his phone records 13 days later, but they are redacted. They are not complete. And, you know, the police that are working with him are saying listen, can you hand this stuff over because in the form that you are handing them over, there is not enough information here for us to be able to tell if you were on the phone with your agents and people were making racist or homophobic slurs in the background. We need to be able hear that so that we can figure out what happened here. We can corroborate your story and we can get the people who did so. My only struggle with this story is why has he not turned that over and if he wants this to be a criminal investigation? Without that information it doesn't meet the burden of proof for a criminal investigation. So that's my struggle here. Why not? Why not just hand them over?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, he says that the reason that he didn't do that because there are important people in his phone and his family. And also he says, you know, he is a gay man and he has pictures there he's not -- doesn't want everybody to see them. So Pete, what's interesting is of course, the subtext to this is people saying well maybe this guy made it up. Maybe he is attacking President Trump and "Make America Great Again" and the hat. So he says in the interview -- he wouldn't need to mention a MAGA hat because that is like putting a cherry on racist sundae. He said these men called him a homophobic slur and the "N" word.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know. I mean, none of it adds up, we don't know so I'm not going to say what did or did not happen. Listen, the MAGA hat could be the point or the cherry on top. Who knows? I've never -- I still don't like at all the idea of hate crimes. Either you commit a crime --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But a stance.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, in a different way. Either you commit a crime or you don't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I see.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: What the motivation in your heart is actually doesn't matter at all. Whether you are a racist or a homophobe or whatever, if you mug someone or you rape someone, you assault someone, you are committing a crime. I don't care what your motivations are.  So the whole conversation to me here is absurd. If he made it up, it was probably to make a point or for an ulterior motive about Trump or about racism. I don't know. If he didn't, it's an unfortunate circumstance we may not get to the bottom of. It all feels icky to me and I just -- I don't know where it goes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Dana, one of the interesting angles on this is, could it be that he is the victim. Derrick Johnson, the head of the NAACP saying today the media is demonizing the victim.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, this is kind of a weird thing because the media is covering the story and one of the things that they complained about was the media using the word "allegedly," but actually that's just AP style. That's like what you are taught in journalism school, Juan, right? I mean, they were complaining about using the word allegedly like, no, that's actually what you do in these things. I would say justice is slow and oftentimes we want things in a second, right, if we press a button, the food delivery comes like we want it immediately. And justice takes a long time so we have to give the investigators a little bit more.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Greg, he seems to say these are the guys who did it, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He did say that if these -- if he had said that they were Muslims or Mexicans maybe more people would have believed him, but they are black guys, Nigerians.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, this is where the, again, the media narrative goes up in smoke. I appreciate how careful and restrained we are on this story and how careful and restrained the media is everywhere on this story. Nothing like the Covington story. You want to compare stories. Let's compare the Covington story to the Smollett story, OK.  There are two similar -- the similarity in the rush to judge a specific group. In this case it was the Covington kids. In this case it was a racist homophobic mysterious men that turns out that half of that is gone. It's not racist, right? That part of the piece is gone. But the media will not -- the media will adjust their narrative without admitting their error. They won't say, oops we were wrong on that. Maybe it's just a homophobic attack. To your point, it's an attack. But it's like they kind of ignored the fact that they were wrong on that as well as attributing this to an atmosphere that encourages hostility. This whole thing like, well, this is happening in Trump's America. Even if it's a strange story with a lot of weird holes and some things don't make sense. But you know what, it's about surging hostility and it's about smearing Trump and Trump values. Modern-day lynchings, those were the words that were being used. A lot of this stuff happened in the beginning, in the rush it judgment. And now, we're looking at it and we're going, OK, there is something else going on here. I don't want to believe that he planned it because I don't believe anybody would be sick enough to risk a race war in order to keep his job on a T.V. show. So I'm hoping that that's not true. He might have known these guys. These guys might have planted story. It's extremely strange. But it's the media in my mind that is at fault about this because they created atmosphere that makes it quick to judge anybody. The assumptions are that this is the type of person who did it. It's the rush. It happened with Covington and it happened here and we don't know how this is going to end. We don't know what these guys did. These guys might be innocent. Who knows?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: And maybe to buy social media too because when you have social media you have a (inaudible) to not only tell your version of the story what you think is true but also it's a hate on everybody you disagree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, coming up. Trump's latest physical creating a media fire storm. That's next right here on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Come on in. President Trump's critics in the press now taking on a new role. Media weight watchers. Members of the media actually fat shaming the president after his annual physical results were released. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Listen, I don't care if he weighs close to 300 pounds.

utterances.speaker: SETH MYERS, LATE NIGHT SHOW HOST
utterances.sentences: President Trump claimed that migrants hoping to illegally enter the country through the southern border would "have to be in extremely good shape to get over his proposed border wall." And that makes sense. He is in terrible shape and he can't seem to get over it.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CUOMO, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: He has a terrible diet. To think that you're going to have his kind of vitals on that kind of diet is really fantasy thinking.

utterances.speaker: JOE SCARBOROUGH, CO-HOST, MSNBC
utterances.sentences: I know a guy who's 6'4''

utterances.speaker: MIKA BRZEZINSKI, CO-HOST, MSNBC
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: SCARBOROUGH
utterances.sentences: and weighs --

utterances.speaker: BRZEZINSKI
utterances.sentences: I do too.

utterances.speaker: SCARBOROUGH
utterances.sentences: --and weighs close to 240 pounds.

utterances.speaker: BRZEZINSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCARBOROUGH
utterances.sentences: He does not look like that.

utterances.speaker: BRZEZINSKI
utterances.sentences: No. But it's amazing they're even lying about - he's lying about his health.

utterances.speaker: SCARBOROUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, he's - yes, lying about his health--

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: When I saw this stat, Greg, the first moment I saw it, I said, the Left will not be able to resist. Apparently, 243 pounds is close to 300.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO,
utterances.sentences: Did they go to my school?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They can't do math economically, but - when it comes to your weight. I think that they should put scales in front of the Morning Show studio, in front of the White House press room and then you should have - when you get in - before you get on there, you have to get on the scale and they have to announce your weight. What - how Mika would feel about that? Because you know what, you can't talk about weight if it's women, because that's called fat shaming. But if it's a dude, go right ahead. It's another example of reverse sexism. And you'll see that in my new book "Reverse Sexism" coming out in June - I'm joking. But you know what? I'm kind of for talking about weight, because when I was on "Red Eye" I put on a lot of weight and you know how I lost weight?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Well, I remember that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I lost weight because everybody on Twitter was making fun of how fat I was.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Is that true?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's - that was incentive.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Dana? This is fun.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I would rather release my tax returns than my weight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Those are heavier.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's silly, because you look fantastic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because - no, I'm just telling you that Greg is right. Women do not want to talk about their weight. And so President Harris or Gillibrand or whoever - Gillibrand?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's Gillibrand.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --whoever is going to be in the future, there will be a woman President. I'm--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: And also I'm hosting Fox & Friends this weekend with some crazy guy named Pete, so.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Yes. And it's your love of hand sanitizer that got me in trouble.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Hand sanitizers, don't drink it.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: --only in small doses. Now we haven't talked enough about Russia on this show today. So check out this dash cam video from Russia. Guys just driving along a shady street when a massive sinkhole - not shady like shady tree shady, Greg - and boom - down into a sinkhole like that out of nowhere. Now, my question is why does all these dash cam video come out of Russia? Now there's some fact. The break room kind of checked this sort of fact check, Russians are notoriously bad drivers, I'm told.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not true.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm told. The number of roads fatalities--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know they got to drive in the worst weather--

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: --they double U.S. fatalities. Also insurance fraud is rampant in Russia, so a lot of people have dash cam cameras.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't trust any of your facts.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: These are not facts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You don't even believe in germs.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: These are things that I was told may be coming out of break room, maybe. OK. I will happily push them as facts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Do we have - Greg, do we have one more Instagram question, from our Facebook since we have a little extra time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. What's your favorite unsolved mystery?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Aliens Roswell, New Mexico.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And we know Pete's germs.

utterances.speaker: HEGSETH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How about that guy - the guy who was flying over Tacoma, Washington with all the money and we know what happened--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: D.B. Cooper.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Anything from you?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I don't have one. I'd rather.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I also want to know why the dinosaurs went extinct, although people tell me that we actually have an alien (ph). Whatever. All right, that's it for us. Have a great weekend everybody. See you back here on Monday. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2019 ASC Services II Media, LLC.
